Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Redox Regulation of Protein Kinase Functions in Guard Cell Signaling

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Stomata are pores on the leaf surface through which plants release oxygen and water vapor and take up carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. The size of the stomatal aperture (and hence the exchange of carbon dioxide and water vapor with the atmosphere) is controlled by specialized cells. These cells (called guard cells) change their shape in response to environmental conditions and are responsive to a range of signaling systems within the plant. The goal of this research is to understand how reactive oxygen species and changes in the reducing and oxidizing biochemistry in guard cells regulate an enzyme system (protein kinases) that controls stomatal movements in response to environmental cues. The function of stomata impacts the response of plants to environmental stress (including temperature and drought) and this research should lead to the rational breeding of improved (stress resistant) crop plants. The project will enable cross-disciplinary training of college and high school students (including women and members of underrepresented groups), in emerging fields of high-throughput science at the interface of biology and chemistry.

The project will use multiple approaches including molecular biology, biochemistry, genetics and analytical chemistry to tackle a critical problem in plant biology, i.e., the functions of reactive oxygen species and redox changes in regulating kinase activities and stomatal movements. The central hypothesis is that redox-dependent modification of cysteine residues in key protein kinases provides a versatile means of regulating kinase function in stomatal signaling. This hypothesis will be tested by pursuing two specific objectives: 1) To determine the cysteine modifications of Brassica napus sucrose non-fermenting related kinases. The experiments will enable comprehensive analysis of cysteine modifications in response to abscisic acid (a drought stress hormone) and a bacterial flagellin peptide that is involved in stomatal entrance of plant pathogens. 2) To determine cysteine modifications functional in stomatal movement and how they affect kinase phosphorylation. The experiments will identify the cysteine modifications essential for stomatal movement and analyze cysteine redox changes that regulate kinase activity. This project will reveal novel regulatory mechanisms underlying stomatal movements and will contribute to the emerging concept of redox modulation as a versatile mechanism by which cells regulate important signaling components and processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On plant leaf surfaces, guard cells are highly specialized cells that form microscopic pores called stomata. Stomatal opening and closing mediated by the guard cells control carbon dioxide intake (for organic carbon production), but also inevitably lead to water vapor loss from the plant to the atmosphere. Therefore, guard cell regulation of stomatal apertures is directly related to plant drought tolerance, growth and yield. Crop productivity is essential to human life in terms of biomaterials for clothing, shelter, and other uses, bioenergy and food. This collaborative project has enabled the Chen and Harmon labs at University of Florida and the Assmann lab at Penn State University to provide an in-depth understanding of guard cell kinase regulation, which is important for stomatal opening and closing.

Kinases are proteins that modify other proteins by addition of a phosphate group. The research team has used interdisciplinary approaches including molecular biology, biochemistry, structural biology, genetics, proteomics, mass spectrometry and bioinformatics and tested the central hypothesis, i.e., redox modification of specific amino acids - cysteines - provides a versatile means of regulating kinase function in guard cells. Different cysteine modifications were identified on two important guard cell kinases, SnRK2.4 and SnRK2.6. A comprehensive analysis was done to determine the roles of these redox modifications on kinase activities involved in guard cell responses to a plant hormone that signals the presence of drought. The results have improved our knowledge of specialized redox regulatory mechanisms in guard cells and contributed to the emerging concept of redox modulation as a versatile mechanism by which all living cells regulate important biological processes. In addition, the knowledge has great potential in facilitating improvement of crops with enhanced stress tolerance and productivity.

A better understanding of guard cell functions can be expected to benefit society by informing rational crop engineering/breeding for enhanced stress tolerance and yield. Protein kinases are ubiquitous players in signal transduction in the cells of all organisms, so the results are also pertinent to non-guard cell and non-plant systems. The data, techniques, and resources are of immediate value to a broad range of scientists and have been disseminated via public repositories, publications and conferences/seminars. The project has allowed cross-disciplinary training of students at different levels, including educational and training activities for high school students and teachers. Exposing high school students to modern scientific research and technologies has broad impacts as they identify their interests and ultimately become leaders in science and technology. Preparing highly qualified next generation scientists and citizens is important for building a prosperous society and a sustainable world.
